Brands that can align with the dominant trends and continue to innovate are most likely to ride the challenges and emerge ahead of the pack.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eDownload\u003c/em\u003e \u003ca href=\"/~/media/mckinsey/industries/retail/our insights/the state of fashion 2020 navigating uncertainty/the-state-of-fashion-2020-final.pdf\"\u003eThe State of Fashion 2020\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e, the full report on which this article is based (PDF\u0026ndash;7MB).\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eABOUT THE AUTHOR(S)\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"/our-people/anita-balchandani\"\u003eAnita Balchandani\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e is a partner in McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s London office, where \u003cstrong\u003eShrina Poojara\u003c/strong\u003e is a consultant; \u003cstrong\u003eAchim Berg\u003c/strong\u003e is a senior partner in the Frankfurt office; \u003cstrong\u003eSaskia Hedrich\u003c/strong\u003e is a senior expert in the Munich office; and \u003cstrong\u003eFelix R\u0026ouml;lkens\u003c/strong\u003e is an associate partner in the Berlin office. \u003cstrong\u003eImran Amed\u003c/strong\u003e is the founder, editor-in-chief, and CEO of \u003ca href=\"https://www.businessoffashion.com/\"\u003eThe Business of Fashion\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe authors wish to thank McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s Tiffany Chan and Marilena Schmich, as well as The Business of Fashion\u0026rsquo;s Robb Young, for their contributions to this article.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[SectionHeader 2019]]\n\u003cp\u003eBy Imran Amed, \u003ca href=\"/our-people/anita-balchandani\"\u003eAnita Balchandani\u003c/a\u003e, Marco Beltrami, Achim Berg, Saskia Hedrich, and Felix R\u0026ouml;lkens\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe industry as a whole is embracing new opportunities\u0026mdash;even as dangers lurk.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe year ahead\u003c/strong\u003e will be an awakening after the reckoning of 2018\u0026mdash;a time for fashion companies to look at opportunities and not just at surmounting challenges. The ones that will succeed will have come to terms with the fact that in the new paradigm taking shape around them, some of the old rules simply don\u0026rsquo;t work. Regardless of size and segment, players now need to be nimble, think digital-first, and achieve ever-faster \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/measuring-the-fashion-world\"\u003espeed to market\u003c/a\u003e. They need to take an active stance on social issues, satisfy consumer demands for radical transparency and \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/a-new-textiles-economy-redesigning-fashions-future\"\u003esustainability\u003c/a\u003e, and, most important, have the courage to \u0026ldquo;self-disrupt\u0026rdquo; their own identity and the sources of their old success to realize these changes and win new generations of customers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThey also need to invest in enhancing their productivity and resilience, as the outlook is uncertain. External shocks to the system continue to lurk, and growth cannot be taken for granted.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Video 2019A]]\n\u003cp\u003eThese are some of the findings from our latest report on \u003cem\u003eThe State of Fashion\u003c/em\u003e, written in partnership with the \u003ca href=\"https://www.businessoffashion.com/\"\u003eBusiness of Fashion (BoF)\u003c/a\u003e, which explores the industry\u0026rsquo;s fragmented, complex ecosystem. Our first two reports, \u003ca href=\"#2018update\"\u003elast year\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and \u003ca href=\"#2017update\"\u003ethe year before\u003c/a\u003e, laid the foundation for rigorous in-depth research and analysis, focusing on the themes, issues, and opportunities affecting the sector and its performance. The \u003cem\u003eState of Fashion\u003c/em\u003e is now the largest and most authoritative overview of the industry, surveying more than 275 global fashion executives (approximately 30 percent more than last year) and interviewing thought leaders and pioneers. We also highlight the ten trends that will define the fashion agenda in 2019 (interactive).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[ceros 20191]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe report includes the third readout of our industry benchmark, the McKinsey Global Fashion Index. This database of more than 500 companies allows us to analyze and compare the performance of individual companies with their peers, by category, segment, or region.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSunny intervals but storms ahead\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor fashion players, 2019 will be a year of awakening. External shocks to the system continue to lurk around the corner, and growth cannot be taken for granted: the McKinsey Global Fashion Index forecasts growth of 3.5 to 4.5 percent, slightly below 2018 figures. By geography, the most optimistic about the coming year are executives in North America. By segment, the most positive are executives from \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/luxury-in-the-age-of-digital-darwinism\"\u003eluxury brands\u003c/a\u003e, reflecting their strong growth trajectory in 2018. In all other regions and segments, executives are notably pessimistic, reflecting the potential challenges ahead (Exhibit 1).[[Footnote 19]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAll this comes against a backdrop of the fashion industry having turned a corner in 2018, with increased growth justifying the optimism expressed in last year\u0026rsquo;s global fashion survey. The caution in the economic outlook is also reflected in the BoF\u0026ndash;McKinsey State of Fashion Survey, with 42 percent of respondents expecting conditions to become worse in 2019.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eThe rise of the \u0026lsquo;superwinners\u0026rsquo;\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePolarization continues to be a stark reality in fashion: fully 97 percent of economic profits for the whole industry are earned by just 20 companies, most of them in the luxury segment. Notably, the top 20 group of companies has remained stable over time. Twelve of the top 20 have been a member of the group for the last decade. Long-term leaders include, among others, Inditex, LVMH, and Nike, which have more than doubled their economic profit over the past ten years (Exhibit 2).[[Footnote 20]] According to our estimates, each racked up more than $2 billion in economic profit in 2017.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eTen trends for 2019\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis caution is one of our ten trends to watch in 2019. Another is that \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/india\"\u003eIndia\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;is on the rise\u0026mdash;its growing middle class, powerful manufacturing sector, and increasingly savvy tech have made it an essential destination for fashion companies. Our third trend is Trade 2.0: a warning that companies should make contingency plans for \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/navigating-the-new-realities-of-global-trade\"\u003ea potential shake-up of global value chains\u003c/a\u003e. The apparel trade could be reshaped by new barriers, trade tensions, and uncertainty. However, there may also be new opportunities from growing south\u0026ndash;south trade and the renegotiation of trade agreements.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Image 20191]]\n\u003cp\u003eOn the consumer side, we foresee the end of ownership, as concerns about sustainability grow and consumers and companies alike worry about how to alleviate their impact on the environment. Sustainability, which breaks into our respondents\u0026rsquo; list of the most important challenges for the first time, is evolving from a tick-box exercise into a transformational feature. And \u0026ldquo;woke\u0026rdquo; consumers are also pushing for greater transparency into supply chains\u0026mdash;and rewarding their favorite brands for taking controversial political stands. At the same time, they are demanding ever-quicker and more seamless fulfillment, from mobile shopping to \u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/technology-delivered-implications-for-cost-customers-and-competition-in-the-last-mile-ecosystem\"\u003edrone delivery\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn response, wise companies are self-disrupting before upstarts do it for them, engaging in a digital landgrab to diversify their ecosystem, and using automation and \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/geek-meets-chic-four-actions-to-jump-start-advanced-analytics-in-apparel\"\u003edata analytics\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to produce on demand to reduce waste and react rapidly to trends.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eThe speed of change\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOverall, the industry continues to hover in a state of flux, and the fortunes of individual players can turn with frightening speed. As our ten trends indicate, new markets, new technologies, and shifting consumer needs present opportunities\u0026mdash;but also risks. We predict that 2019 will be a year shaped by consumer shifts linked to technology, social causes, and trust issues, alongside the potential disruption from geopolitical and macroeconomic events. Only those brands that accurately reflect the Zeitgeist or have the courage to \u0026ldquo;self-disrupt\u0026rdquo; will emerge as winners.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eDownload\u003c/em\u003e \u003ca href=\"/~/media/mckinsey/industries/retail/our insights/the state of fashion 2019 a year of awakening/the-state-of-fashion-2019-final.pdf\"\u003eThe State of Fashion 2019\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e, the full report on which this article is based (PDF\u0026ndash;3 MB).\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eABOUT THE AUTHOR(S)\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"/our-people/anita-balchandani\"\u003eAnita Balchandani\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e is a partner in McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s London office, where \u003cstrong\u003eMarco Beltrami\u003c/strong\u003e is a consultant; \u003cstrong\u003eAchim Berg\u003c/strong\u003e is a senior partner in the Frankfurt office, \u003cstrong\u003eSaskia Hedrich\u003c/strong\u003e is a senior expert in the Munich office, and \u003cstrong\u003eFelix R\u0026ouml;lkens\u003c/strong\u003e is a consultant in the Berlin office. \u003cstrong\u003eImran Amed\u003c/strong\u003e is the founder, editor-in-chief, and CEO of the \u003ca href=\"https://www.businessoffashion.com/\"\u003eBusiness of Fashion\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe authors wish to thank McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s Johanna Andersson and Dale Kim, as well as the Business of Fashion\u0026rsquo;s Robb Young, for their contributions to this work.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ca id=\"2018update\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n[[SectionHeader 2018]]\n\u003cp\u003eBy  Imran Amed, Johanna Andersson, Achim Berg, Martine Drageset, Saskia Hedrich, and Sara Kappelmark\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAfter a challenging stretch, has fashion turned the corner? Things are looking up, but the rebound may be uneven, says this year\u0026rsquo;s The \u003cem\u003eState of Fashion\u003c/em\u003e report.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThere is general agreement\u003c/strong\u003e that 2016 was one of the most challenging years the fashion industry has ever seen. But we are now detecting glimmers of hope: executives report optimism (even amid uncertainty), and the McKinsey Global Fashion Index forecasts industry sales growth to nearly triple between 2016 and 2018, from 1.5 percent to between 3.5 and 4.5 percent. Emerging markets remain a crucial source of this growth; indeed, in 2018, for the first time, more than half of apparel and footwear sales will originate outside Europe and North America.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese are some of the findings from our latest \u003cem\u003eThe State of Fashion\u003c/em\u003e report, written in partnership with the \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.businessoffashion.com/\"\u003eBusiness of Fashion (BoF)\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e to explore the industry\u0026rsquo;s fragmented, complex ecosystem. \u003ca href=\"#2017update\"\u003eOur first report\u003c/a\u003e, last year, laid the foundation for rigorous in-depth research and analysis, focusing on the themes, issues, and opportunities affecting the sector and its performance. (For more, see our infographic on the ten trends that will define the fashion agenda in 2018.) This year, we are seeing real signs of change.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Ceros 20181]]\n\u003ch3\u003eFashion\u0026rsquo;s growth outlook by region, and by category\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough the fashion industry appears to be turning a corner, the rebound is not being felt evenly across the globe. In fact, 2017 signals the end of an era, as the West will no longer be the global stronghold for fashion sales\u0026mdash;more than half of apparel and footwear sales will originate outside of Europe and North America. The main sources of growth are emerging-market countries across Asia\u0026ndash;Pacific, Latin America, and other regions; they are forecasted to grow at rates ranging between 5 and 7.5 percent in 2018 (exhibit).[[footnote 21]] Meanwhile, the economic outlook in the mature part of Europe is stable, and fashion-industry sales growth is likewise expected to remain at a modest but steady 2 to 3 percent. In North America, while overall consumer confidence is strong, the impact of policy changes is uncertain, and markdown pressures, market corrections, and store closures continue. Here, we expect a modest growth of 1 to 2 percent. Not surprisingly, this regional divide is reflected in fashion executives\u0026rsquo; sentiments, as respondents to the BoF\u0026ndash;McKinsey Global Fashion Survey from emerging countries are more optimistic about the industry\u0026rsquo;s outlook in 2018 than their European or North American counterparts.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe outlook for the fashion industry varies across different value segments, too. \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/the-two-faces-of-fashion-industry-performance\"\u003eThe industry continues to polarize\u003c/a\u003e: consumers are trading away from the midmarket price points even while the luxury, value, and discount segments are picking up speed. When it comes to categories, the improvement of fashion-industry sales is reflected in stronger sales growth forecasts across the board, including apparel and footwear. Handbags and luggage, and to some extent watches and jewelry, are returning slowly to their historic highs, driven by demand in Asia\u0026ndash;Pacific. Athletic wear is the only category where record growth rates look to slow down slightly in 2018, as the \u0026ldquo;athleisure\u0026rdquo; trend has reached its peak in some mature markets. Nonetheless, this is still expected to be the fastest-growing category, with continued strong demand in many markets.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eShifts among consumers\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese developments take place at the same time as the fashion industry goes through other transformative shifts. Mainstream customers are \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/the-consumer-sector-in-2030-trends-and-questions-to-consider\"\u003emoving into a decisive phase of digital adoption\u003c/a\u003e, and online sales of apparel and footwear are projected to grow rapidly. Consumers in Southeast Asia spend about eight hours a day online on average. The modern shopper\u0026rsquo;s comfort with digital channels and content has created a complex customer journey across online and offline touchpoints. But regardless of touchpoint, \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/mastering-the-digital-advantage-in-transforming-customer-experience\"\u003econsumers expect a consistent brand experience\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;across channels. Consumers also have higher expectations of \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/the-ceo-guide-to-customer-experience\"\u003ecustomer experience\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and scrutinize convenience, price, quality, and newness. Digital-first companies such as Alibaba, Amazon, Net-a-Porter, and Zappos continue to force fashion companies to provide an even more premium experience. Many consumers today expect perfect functionality and immediate support at all times, coupled with rapid delivery times as players constantly compete to expedite products.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[image 2018cover]]\n\u003cp\u003eCustomers\u0026rsquo; attention is also tuned to new channels. This has a profound impact as purchase decisions are influenced by social media, peer reviews, influencer marketing, and traditional marketing, and even many purchases themselves are made consumer-to-consumer. With information and the ease of comparison at their fingertips, \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/the-new-battleground-for-marketing-led-growth\"\u003econsumers are becoming less brand loyal\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;among millennials, two-thirds say they are willing to switch brands for a discount of 30 percent or more. Shoppers are also becoming more selective. More and more, they base their purchase decisions on whether a company\u0026rsquo;s practices and mission aligns with their values\u0026mdash;while at the same time they are highly price sensitive.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo consumers expect it all: convenience, quality, values orientation, newness, and price. In response, leading fashion players are offering innovative business models,\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/quantumblack/our-insights/capturing-value-from-your-customer-data\"\u003e using granular customer insights\u003c/a\u003e as a source of differentiation, and pushing the limits of go-to-market times. Sales of the traditional fast-fashion sector have grown by more than 20 percent over the last three years, and new online fast-fashion players are gaining ground. To keep up, leading fashion players are accelerating their speed from design to shelf. This \u0026ldquo;need for speed\u0026rdquo; is driven partly by social media accelerating the movement of fashion trends to the masses, and by industry leaders using analytics and customer insights to meet customer needs better and increase responsiveness.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut speed and flexibility bring added complexity. Shortening lead times requires major changes to the traditional business model and supply chain, and \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/the-next-generation-operating-model-for-the-digital-world\"\u003ea shift in focus to a customer-centric model\u003c/a\u003e. Laggards face increased fashion risk and excess inventory if they fail to match customer demand. Frontrunners are building agile supply chains supported by higher-quality consumer insights\u0026mdash;with the frontier being close to a real-time supply chain fed by \u0026ldquo;test and learn\u0026rdquo; and data analytics.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the light of all this change, the performance gap between frontrunners and laggards continues to widen: from 2005 to 2015, the top 20 percent of fashion companies contributed 100 percent of the industry\u0026rsquo;s entire economic profit; in 2016, the top 20 percent\u0026rsquo;s contribution had increased to 144 percent.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe challenges of a fundamentally changing industry and a continued unpredictable macroeconomic environment has led fashion players to toughen up. Industry players are coming to accept unpredictability as the new norm, and fashion executives will in 2018 respond by focusing their energy on improving what is within their control. For those leaning forward and willing to help design the new features of the modern fashion system, the opportunities at hand to truly connect with fashion consumers across the globe have never been greater.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eDownload\u003c/em\u003e \u003ca href=\"/~/media/mckinsey/industries/retail/our insights/renewed optimism for the fashion industry/the-state-of-fashion-2018-final.pdf\"\u003eThe State of Fashion 2018\u003c/a\u003e \u003cem\u003eto view the exhibit and read the full report on which this article is based (PDF\u0026ndash;3 MB).\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eABOUT THE AUTHOR(S)\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eJohanna Andersson\u003c/strong\u003e is a consultant in McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s Stockholm office, where \u003cstrong\u003eSara Kappelmark\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;is a partner; \u003cstrong\u003eAchim Berg\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;is a senior partner in the Frankfurt office, \u003cstrong\u003eMartine Drageset\u003c/strong\u003e is a consultant in the Oslo office, and \u003cstrong\u003eSaskia Hedrich\u003c/strong\u003e is a senior expert in the Munich office. \u003cstrong\u003eImran Amed\u003c/strong\u003e is the founder, editor-in-chief, and CEO of the \u003cem\u003eBusiness of Fashion\u003c/em\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ca id=\"2017update\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n[[SectionHeader 2017]]\n\u003cp\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003eFashion is one\u003c/strong\u003e of the past decade\u0026rsquo;s rare economic success stories. Over that period, the industry has grown at 5.5 percent annually, according to the McKinsey Global Fashion Index, to now be worth an estimated $2.4 trillion. In fact, not only does it touch everyone, but it would be the world\u0026rsquo;s seventh-largest economy if ranked alongside individual countries\u0026rsquo; GDP.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nYet 2016 was one of the industry\u0026rsquo;s toughest years. Terrorist attacks in France, the Brexit vote in the United Kingdom, and the volatility of the Chinese stock market have created shocks to the global economy. At the same time, \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/saving-scrimping-and-splurging-new-insights-into-consumer-behavior\"\u003econsumers have become more demanding, more discerning, and less predictable in their purchasing behavior\u003c/a\u003e, which is being radically reshaped by new technologies. It\u0026rsquo;s against this backdrop that McKinsey has teamed with \u003ca rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" href=\"https://www.businessoffashion.com/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ethe Business of Fashion\u003c/a\u003e to shine a light on the fragmented, complex ecosystem that underpins this giant global industry.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e2016: A year to forget\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOur first \u003ca href=\"/~/media/mckinsey/industries/retail/our insights/the state of fashion 2017/the-state-of-fashion-mck-bof-2017-report.pdf\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe State of Fashion\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e report (PDF\u0026ndash;8MB) finds that it\u0026rsquo;s not only external shock waves that have roiled the industry. Companies have also been looking inward, implementing changes to the core operations that are reshaping the entire fashion system, from shortening the length of the fashion cycle to integrating sustainable innovation into the core product-design and manufacturing processes. Perhaps unsurprisingly, 67 percent of executives said conditions for the fashion industry have worsened over the past 12 months.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis fact is clearly borne out in the industry\u0026rsquo;s financial performance. Sales growth seems set to slow to a mere 2 or, at most, 3 percent by the close of 2016, with stagnating profit margins. Speculation and uncertainty over the repercussions of the US election outcome could further dampen consumer sentiment and affect sales. This is in stark contrast to the fashion industry\u0026rsquo;s performance over the previous decade, which saw the industry expand at 5.5 percent annually.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYet this sluggish overall growth masks some big winners: affordable luxury, value, and athletic wear.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[image cover]]\n\u003cp\u003eWith respect to sales growth, the affordable-luxury and value sectors have outperformed all other segments by one to one-and-a-half percentage points. This is consistent with their compound annual growth rate (CAGR) over the past three years, which has been 9 percent for affordable luxury and 6 percent for value, the highest of any segment since 2013.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAffordable-luxury players benefited from consumers trading down from luxury, \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/chinese-consumers-revisiting-our-predictions\"\u003eparticularly among Chinese consumers\u003c/a\u003e. However, their profit margins are expected to decline, especially after 2016, because of a pricing-arbitrage disadvantage across geographies and fluctuating foreign-exchange rates.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe value segment continued to grow in 2016, particularly as a consequence of large global players expanding geographically. With its clearly defined value proposition, the value segment has been taking share from discount this year.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn 2016, the 8.0 to 8.5 percent growth for athletic wear is more than double any other category. This is consistent with its 10 percent CAGR of the past decade, driven by consumers\u0026rsquo; more active lifestyles, the rise of \u0026ldquo;athleisure,\u0026rdquo; emerging brands in the high-end segments, and product innovations. As athletic wear continues to grow, it will become a category with the ability to compete on equal terms with clothing and footwear, particularly in the midmarket and premium segments.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e2017: Glimmers of recovery\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo what will change in 2017? No one would put money on volatility and uncertainty lessening. Nonetheless, our report finds that fashion companies are hopeful they can improve their performance through a combination of organic growth and \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/digitizing-the-consumer-decision-journey\"\u003eleveraging new technologies\u003c/a\u003e. Successful companies will invest more to nurture local clientele: 2017 will be the year of organic growth by deepening relationships with existing clients, rather than through geographic, channel, and store-network expansion. And \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/is-luxury-ecommerce-nearing-its-tipping-point\"\u003edigital innovation\u003c/a\u003e will go behind the scenes: digitization will be the key to supply-chain efficiency, lowering procurement costs, and the enhancement of sourcing opportunities.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSome 40 percent of executives we interviewed expect conditions for the fashion industry to improve in 2017, compared with the 19 percent who reported improving conditions in 2016 (exhibit).[[footnote 22]] This is particularly true for the major players within each of the market segments and product categories. Many of them have already undertaken significant cost cutting and restructuring, and they are now primed to capture the benefits.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAll things considered, we expect fashion-industry growth will increase to 2.5 to 3.5 percent in 2017, although the days when the industry outpaced GDP growth by as much as two percentage points seem over. A return to the riches of the previous decade appears unlikely. But equally, there is no call for rags just yet.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePerformance will vary depending on the individual dynamics of specific market segments and categories. Value and affordable luxury will probably be the big winners, both outpacing the industry average at a projected 3.0 to 4.0 percent and 3.5 to 4.5 percent growth, respectively. That said, almost all other market segments should see a slight improvement in sales growth of half to one-and-a-half percentage points. Only the discount segment is likely not to be part of the recovery trend.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eProduct categories are expected to grow in line with the overall industry average, but the biggest winners will be those companies with coherent channel strategies and clear value definitions. Athletic wear is set to become the absolute category champion, maintaining 6.5 to 7.5 percent sales growth, although it will be unable to reproduce the double-digit growth of the past. The affordable-luxury segment seems likely to continue benefiting from consumers trading down from luxury, while signs point to the continued growth of the value segment as large global players expand internationally.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn short, the industry next year has an opportunity to stabilize and reset, and success stories will probably be written by those already planning for the year ahead. They should bear in mind the three trends that we believe will shape the 2017 fashion industry: the global economy, consumer behavior, and the fashion business model.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEconomically, we see a number of trends that will shape the industry, including fashion\u0026rsquo;s response to intensifying volatility, \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/china/the-ceo-guide-to-chinas-future\"\u003econtinued challenges in China\u003c/a\u003e, and \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/urbanization/urban-world-meeting-the-demographic-challenge-in-cities\"\u003ethe rise of urban centers\u003c/a\u003e. To address consumer behavior, players will have to learn to serve shrewder and more-demanding customers and adjust to a shifting demographic profile. Finally, 2017 will also be a critical year for the fashion business system, with developments expected around the fashion cycle, technological advancements, and a shake-up in the ownership of fashion companies, as players restructure and industry outsiders step up their activities in the fashion sector.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe bottom line is that amid this uncertainty and change, our analysis suggests cautious optimism is warranted. It\u0026rsquo;s a sentiment shared by industry executives: 40 percent expect conditions for the industry to improve in the year ahead. As with everything in this fast-moving sector, we\u0026rsquo;ll just have to wait and see.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eThis is an edited excerpt from the first joint report from McKinsey
